cab.content: SECRET. MINISTET OF FOOD. Report for Week ending Wednesday, April 30, 1919.ill ' "' PART I. ACTION TAKEN. Food Council. The Food Council met on April 24th and 29th. It was agreed that it was desirable that, on the dissolution of the Ministry of Food,responsibility for work in connection with the production of forma should be trans-ferred to the Board of Agriculture, from which Department it was originally taken overby the Food Controller. One mill at King's Lynn is now in operation and threeothers, work on which is well advanced, will be completed as soon as finalexperiments have been carried out at King's Lynn. Since there is a steady demand forfarina for use in the textile trades, as well as for food purposes, and since the demandfor potatoes, as the raw material of the industry, will be of great value in stabilisingpotato prices when there are large supplies, it was considered that the establishment and maintenance of this industry is of considerable importance. A proposal to suspend the maximum fish prices still in force was considered. Itwas decided that the maximum prices for herrings and mackerel should be suspendedas from May 15th, but that the remaining maximum prices, on such fish as salmon,sole and turbot, should be retained for the present. The question of the compensation to be paid to farmers in respect of abnormalwastage to potatoes was again considered and it was agreed (1) that in certain scheduled districts local committees representing the Ministry of Food and the farmers, with an impartial chairman, should be set up to investigate claims in respect of loss and to report the facts to the Food Controller with a view to compensation or ex gratia payments being made where the circumstances justified such a course. (2) that differences arising between, the Food Controller and the potato growers on the question of liability may be referred to arbitration. (3) that in districts not included in the schedule, claims should be sent direct to the Divisional Food Commissioner. It was decided that, with a view to removing the present hardship of British importers of frozen meat resulting from the small amount of Australasian meat available for distribution, the stocks of South American meat released for civilian consumption should be handed to the Associated Meat Importers' Committee to be divided between the British agents and the agents of the South American companies in the proportion of the total volume of trade handled by them respectively before the war. H.M. Treasury having again refused to sanction the purchase of the, exportable surplus of Canadian cheese it was agreed not to press the matter further, but to warn H.M. Treasury that their decision may involve entering the market at a later date and purchasing the supplies required at an enhanced price. The Consumers'1 Council. The Council meet on April 30th. The Council again expressed the opinion that it was desirable in the interests of the consumer that the existence of the Ministry of Food should be continued. The Food Controller, who was present at the meeting, assured the Council that their views would be laid before the Cabinet. The following resolution on fish prices was passed: "The Council views with concern the fact that the retail prices of fish are higher than those which the Food Ministry publishes from time to time as being reasonable, and urges that immediate action be taken to stop this profiteering." Imports Board. Private traders are experiencing difficulty in arranging for the shipment of bacon, hams and lard, and, as the Ministry's shippings in these com- modities are practically over, stocks will decrease rapidly during May. It is A (33)8000-1 Pkll) 150 5/19 E&S A anticipated that the position will become serious unless considerable supplies are forthcoming on private account. It is hoped, however, that it will be possible for the necessary arrangements for securing tonnage to be made shortly. The Ministry of Food are taking over 1,200 tons of War Office cheese now on' passage to this country from Egypt. The New Zealand stock is estimated to be 35,000 tons, but shipments continue to be meagre. Steps will be taken to limit arrivals of cheese in this country from July to October, during which months large quantities may be expected from Canada, to an amount that can be effectively handled. In order that a close watch may be kept' on the position, it is proposed to require private traders to furnish particulars of their shipments and expected arrivals. RELAXATION OF EXPORT AND IMPORT RESTRICTIONS. Export Restrictions. At the date of the Armistice the list of prohibited goods included 120 commodities with which the Ministry of Food were concerned. Of these over 50 have now been either removed from the list or freed from any restrictions so far as the Ministry are concerned. In addition, in many cases it has been possible for manufactured articles to be freed from restriction, although it has been necessary to retain control of the raw material. The foodstuffs which have thus been set free for export include all kinds of potted, preserved, and frozen fish, except canned salmon; pickles, spices, sauces, tinned and potted meats; honey, saccharin, syrup, moist sugar, molasses, aerated mineral waters and manufactured articles containing sugar, except such goods as jam and confectionery; arrowroot, cornflour, dextrine, mandioca and certain other cereal products ; and wine and spirits, except whisky. In addition to alterations which have thus been made in the prohibited list, the Ministry of Food have agreed that certain important foodstuffs which it is not con- sidered possible to remove at once from the list, should be licensed for export to approved destinations either without limit or else in very large quantities ; these include cocoa powder, raw cocoa, block cocoa, dates, tea, coffee and tomato pulp. A more limited export is also allowed in respect of confectionery, malt and malt products, lemons, oranges, yeast, prepared suets and other commodities. Moreover, the quantity of. beer and ale which may be exported has recently been increased from one-third, to two-thirds of pre-war exports. Of the classes of articles in respect of which the Food Controller is still unable to authorise the removal from the prohibited list, more than 30 are cereals and animal feeding stuffs ; others are essential or important foodstuffs and raw materials of which there is still a shortage of supply, including, in addition to those named in the previous paragraph, sugar, butter, cheese, eggs, meat and poultry, fruits (other than lemons and oranges), onions, edible oils and fats, oleaginous kernels and seeds. The question of the removal of condensed milk from the list is now under consideration with H.M. Treasury. Import Restrictions. At the date of the signing of the Armistice the following were the most important foodstuffs of which the importation was prohibited except under licenpe : bacon, hams and lard, beer, spirits and wine, butter and cheese, cocoa, tea and coffee, canned salmon, canned, bottled, dried and preserved fruits, except currants, raw fruit, except lemons and bitter oranges, sugar and preparations containing sugar. During November general licences were issued permitting the importation from all sources of apples, bananas, almonds and nuts used as fruit, canned, bottled andpreserved fruits and raw cocoas. General licences have also now been issued in thecase of the following foodstuffs: bacon, hams, lard, tea, coffee, dried fruits, cannedbottled and preserved fruits, sweet oranges, tinned lobsters, crabs, prawns and oysters, vegetables (except gherkins in brine), canned, bottled, dried and preservedvegetables, soya beans, tallow, cocoa powder, yeast, brandy, rum, Geneva Hollands,liqueurs and wine. The Ministry of Food are also in communication with the Department of Import Restrictions with a view to the prohibition being removed in the case of the fol-lowing articles : cocoa butter, canned, bottled, dried and preserved vegetables, olive oil, raw fruit of. all kinds, jam, confectionery and other goods included under the heading " articles containing sugar " which may be agreed by the Sugar Commission, tomatoes, and stearine. ' . . The maintenance of the prohibitions on beer, sugar, butter, cheese, canned salmon and the Norwegian canned fish is considered necessary for the present. Itmust, however, be remembered in this connection, that the Board of Trade haverecently issued a general licence permitting the free importation of Colonial products,and that existing prohibitions accordingly apply only to foreign products other thanFrench, which are entitled to admission under an international agreement. Licences are now being granted freely by the Royal Commission on the SugarSupply for private imports of sugar from foreign countries. SUPPLIES AND DISTRIBUTION. Rationing. The coupons in the current ration books come to an end on May 3rd,and while no coupons will be required for the purchase of any kind of food after thatdate, the ration books will still be needed in connection with the rationing of meat,sugar and butter, which, will probably continue until June 30th. During this periodcustomers will continue to be registered with retailers but a freer exchange of retailerwill be allowed than has hitherto been the case. It is proposed to abolish all rationing and the registration of customers on June 30th, but it will still be necessary to control the distribution of meat, sugar and butter to retailers for a further, period. Meat. Owing to the holding back of stock, with a view to the increase of the wholesale price on May 1st, the supply of live stock has recently been deficient. Ashome-killed and frozen meat will no longer be sold at the same price after May 3rd, itwill be necessary that both varieties should be on sale at the same time and it is accordingly proposed to discontinue the policy of supplying districts with only frozenmeat in alternate weeks. A deputation of London retail butchers waited on the Director of Meat supplies on Monday April 28th with reference to the grading and allocation of certaindescriptions of imported meat. A satisfactory arrangement was arrived at by whichthe butchers were given the right of nominating four representatives to act with theGrading Committee appointed by the Smithfield Control Board to deal Avith theallocation of imported meat. . ORDERS UNDER DEFENCE OF THE REALM REGULATIONS. The Milk (Summer Prices) Order, 1919, dated 24th April 19.19, fixes wholesaleand retail prices for milk from May to September. The Order embodies the recom-mendations of the Travelling Commission on milk, details of which were given in theReports of April 9th and 23rd. Directions under the Milk (Distribution) and (Regis-tration) Orders give effect to the scheme of differential prices for milk. The Seed, Nuts, Kernels, Oils and Fats (Maximum Prices) Order, 1919, dated28th April 1919, fixes maximum wholesale and retail prices for copra, cotton-seed,ground nuts-and palm kernels, and the refined and crude oils obtained therefrom. The Dripping (Standard of Quality) Order, 1919, dated 28th April 1919, fixesa standard quality for dripping, whether home-produced or imported. The Spirits (Prices and Description) Order, 1919, dated 30th April 1919, comes into operation on May 1st. The effect is to raise the maximum price per bottleof 30 under proof to 10.9. Qd. The Intoxicating Liquor (Output and Delivery) Order 1919, No. 2, dated 30th April,.increases the permitted standard barrelage of beer to an amount approximately equalto 52 per cent, of the pre-war consumption and permits the average gravity of eachbrewer in Great Britain to be raised to 10400. The following Orders have been revoked as from April 30th : The Oil Splitting Order, 1917. The Oils, Oil Cakes and Meals (Requisition) Order, 1917, so far as it relates to crude oils. The Hardened Fat (Requisition) Order, 1917. The Home Melt Tallow and Greases (Maximum Prices) Order, 1918.. The Bones (Maximum Prices) Order, 1918. The Seeds Nuts and Kernels (Requisition) Order, 1917. The Oils and Fats (Requisition) Order, 1917, except as to certain shipments made before a fixed date. The Edible Oils (Maximum Prices) Order, 1919. A 2 The following Orders, relating to cattle feeding stuffs, are revoked as from april 30th :- The Cattle Feeding Stuffs (Committees) Order, 1917. The Cattle Feeding Stuffs (Maximum Prices) Order, 1918. The Cattle Feeding Stuffs (Requisition) Order, 1918. The Cattle Feeding Stuffs (Distribution) Order, 1918. The Oils, Oil Cahes and Meals (Requisition) Order, 1917. The effect of the revocation of the above Orders is to restore freedom of trade inall cattle feeding stuffs with the exception of flour millers' offals, the prices of whichex mill will still be regulated. ENFORCEMENT OF ORDERS. The total number of prosecutions during the fortnight ended April 19tli was1,253, of which 1,135 were successful.PART II. SUMMARY OF THE FOOD POSITION. IMPORTS. The total imports of the principal foods and feeding-stuffs, which in the precedingweek had advanced to 156,900 tons, rose sharply in the week ended 26th April to205,800 tons. This is considerably above the average for the first 19 weeks of the calendar year (150,200 tons) and that for the current cereal year to date (165,500tons). Sugar accounts for practically the whole of the increase on the precedingweek, arrivals of this. commodity rising from 22,900 tons to 68,200 tons, a record quantity for recent years. Arrivals of cereals (91,000 tons) also showed afurther improvement on the figures for preceding weeks, and the quantity of bacon(19,000 tons) was the largest received in any one week this year. Meat, however, felloff from 19,800 tons in the preceding week to 12,900 tons. Of the less bulky commoditities, butter (2,300 tons) continued to arrive in comparatively large quantities, but. cheese (700 tons) and lard (500 tons) compare unfavourably with the average weekly quantities received this year. This appliesalso to condensed milk, the actual quantity of which, however, 1,600 tons, is still verylarge. Imports of tea, coffee and cocoa, continue considerably above the pre-waraverage. In the week ended 26th April the tea received (3,300 tons) was only slightlybelow the average for recent months, while coffee (1,600 tons) and cocoa (3,900 tons)were both largely in. excess of it. The figures for the first 34- weeks of the cereal years 1917-18 and 1918-19 arecompared in the following table :-Total Imports for the first 34 weeks of Cereal Year (4i/i September to 2Qth April).Total -wheat flour -Equivalent. as Grain.Bice -Barley, oats, and maize.jVIeat -1918-1!).Increase or Decrease on 1917-1S. Total stocks of meat and provisions in cold stores and importers' warehouses on19th April showed a slight general downward movement. The one exception was inthe case of canned meats (31,100 tons), which showed an increase of 2,300 tons onstocks already equal to a years supply. Stocks of butter (12,000 tons) also maintainedthe high level of the preceding week.' Of the commodities showing a decrease, themost important were cheese, which fell by 2,300 tons to 5,600 tons, and bacon, which fell by 3,200 tons to 31,700 tons. On the other hand stocks of these commodities heldby the Ministry rose ; the increase of 800 tons in cheese, making a stock of 6,500 tons,is explained by the fact that no distribution occurred during the week, while theMinistry stock also includes large imports of the preceding week in process of transportover the country. In the case of bacon, there was a drop in the quantity allocatedfrom Government stocks, which now represent about one-half of the total stocks incold stores and importers' warehouses. Of the other stocks held by the Ministry on19th April, butter (14,000 tons or 9 weeks' supply), lard (12,800 tons or 4 weeks'supply) and refrigerated meat (25,500 tons or under a week's total requirements of meat), showed small decreases, while tea (40,000 tons or 13 weeks' supply) and driedfruits (24,500 tons) rose slightly. WHOLESALE PRICES. Average wholesale prices for April as compared with those for March showed aslight upward tendency in home-grown cereals, wheat rising from 72s. M. to 72s. lid.per quarter, and barley from 62s. fid. to 62s. 9d. ; on the other hand maize fell from64s. to 60s. per quarter. The reduction of the flat wholesale rates (home and imported)for beef and for mutton, rendered necessary by the lower retail prices fixed in March,is reflected fully in the average April prices, which were 116s. Sd. and 123s. Sd. percwt. respectively, as against 121s. Id. and 128s. Id., respectively, for March. Thesame course of events accounts for the further reduction in cheese from 159s. 9d. to144s. Sd. per cwt. Under the Bacon and Ham (Prices) Order, 1919, the average price for home-produced bacon rose from 194s. M. to 200s. M. per cwt.; as against this,measures of decontrol resulted in a slight decrease in the average price of Canadianbacon from 185s. to 184s. bd. per cwt. Measures of decontrol are also responsible for.the decrease in the wholesale price of India and Ceylon tea from Is. 4tL to Is. Id.per lb., the average for April being Is. 2d. There was a general downward tendency in the price of oilseeds and oilcake, linseed (Calcutta) falling from 7I5s. to .597s. M.per ton, palm kernels from 539s. to 516s. od., and cottonseed cake from 300s. to297s. Qd,; on the other hand cottonseed (Egyptian) rose from 376s. to 380s. per ton.A 8000-T TABLE A. The figures for wheat and Hour include stocks in port granaries and warehouses, inland warehouses,mills, and bakers' shops, as well as estimated stocks on farms ; those for barley, oats, beans, and peasinclude stocks in port granaries and warehouses and in mills, in maltsters' hands, and estimated farm stocks ;those for maize, rice, and grain meals include stocks in port granaries and warehouses and in mills. The figures for sugar are stocks in possession of the Sugar Commission ; those for butter, margarine,lard, cheese, condensed milk, meat, and fish include stocks at ports, in cold stores, and in importers' andwholesalers' warehouses. The figures for tea, coffee, and cocoa are stocks remaining in bonded warehouses or entered to bewarehoused ; and those for oilseeds and oilseed cake include stocks at ports and in the hands of millers,crushers and cake manufacturers. ,i Article.
